dict.string: Introduce yourself and your role clearly to the patient.

Explain the procedure, and gain consent from the patient. Be sure to mention any findings will be kept confidential between the treating team. Ensure the patient is adequately exposed and correctly positioned.
Hand hygiene is a simple and effective solution to reduce both the spread of infection and multiresistant germs, and to protect patients from healthcare-associated infection.

Ensure the patient isn't in any acute distress. Is there any obvious signs of dyspnea or cyanosis? Make a comment on the patient's general appearance. Cachexia is commonly caused by malignancy, but may also be caused by severe cardiac failure.
Coldness and color may indicate poor peripheral vascular supply. Capillary refill should be within 2 seconds.
Cause is unknown, can be due to cyanotic congenital heart disease, infective endocarditis, lung carcinoma, bronchiectasis, lung abscess, idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis and many others
Linear haemorrhages along the long axis of the nail. Usually due to trauma, but importantly may be caused by infective endocarditis. Other causes are vasculitis, sepsis and haematological malignancy.

Osler's Node: Red raised tender nodules on pulps of fingers or toes, or thenar and hypothenar eminence. They are rare. Caused by infective endocarditis. Janeway lesions: Non-tender erythematous maculopapular lesions containing bacteria, on the palms of pulps of fingers. Also rare. Caused by infective endocarditis.
Deposits of lipids, yellow or orange in colour occurring over the tendons of the hand and arm. Caused by hyperlipidaemia.
Radial pulse, radial-radial delay, and radiofemoral delay

Note regularity and rate. Normal rate should be between 60-100. Radial-radial delay may be present in cases of large arterial occlusions by atherosclerotic plaque. Radiofemoral delay indicates coarctation of the aorta.A collapsing pulse indicates aortic regurgitation, pulsus alternans indicated severe left ventricular failure.
Normal ranges: BP 110-135 systolic and 70-85 diastolic, temp 36.1-37.5, SpO2 >96%, RR 12-20
Can occur with severe congestive heart failure and hepatic congestion. Prosthetic heart valves can also cause haemolysis of red blood cells.
Yellow cholesterol deposits around the eyes, relatively common. Can be a normal variant or may indicate Type II or III hyperlipidaemia.
Grey circle seen around the outer aspect of the pupil, and associated with increased cardiovascular risk.
Rosy red cheeks with a blueish tinge, due to dilatation of malar capillaries. Associated with pulmonary hypertension and mitral stenosis. Quite rare.
Occurs in Marfan's syndrome, which is associated with congenital heart disease as well as aortic and mitral regurgitation.
Diseased teeth or recent dental surgery can be a source of infective endocarditis.
Inspect the tongue and lips for central cyanosis. The mucosa should be inspected for petechiae which may indicate infective endocarditis
Position medial to the sternomastoid muscles. Never palpate both carotid arteries! Palpate for character, and auscultate for signs of bruits.

Provides information on right atrial and ventricular function. Position the patient at 45 degrees. Measure from the sternal angle. JVP above 3 cm indicates increased right heart filling pressure; a sign of right ventricular failure, volume overload, or pericardial disease.

Evidence of any scars or pacemakers. Pectus excavatum (funnel chest) or kyphoscoliosis. Look for the apex beat, normal position is in the left fifth intercostal space, 1 cm medial to the midclavicular line.

Palpate the apex beat (left fifth intercostal space, 1 cm medial to the midclavicular line). It is only palpable in around 50% of patients. Abnormal apex beats may be due to pressure overload (aortic stenosis, hypertension), volume overloaded (mitral regurgitation, dilated cardiomyopathy). Character of the apex beat may become more apparent with the patient lying on their left hand side. Also palpate for any parasternal heaves and valvular thrills.
Begin in the mitral area (apex) with the bell as well as the diaphragm of the stethoscope.
The tricuspid area is located at the fifth left intercostal space. Use the diaphragm of the stethoscope.
The pulmonary area is located at the left sternal edge, second intercostal space. Use the diaphragm of the stethoscope.
The aortic area is located at the right sternal edge, second intercostal space. Use the diaphragm of the stethoscope.
Percuss the back to exclude a pleural effusion; can be due to left ventricular failure.
Presence of inspiratory crackles may be due to congestive cardiac failure.
Can occur in severe right heart failure.
An enlarged, tender liver may be a sign of right heart failure due to congestion of the hepatic veins.
May occur in severe right heart failure.
Palpate in the left of the middle line. Often palpable in thinner people, but should be pulsatile but not expansile (abdominal aortic aneurysm).

Palpate behind the medial malleolus of the tibia, and the distal shaft of the tibia. Use thumb and compress for 15 seconds. Pitting oedema occurs in the presence of heart failure, or lymphadenopathy. Note the level at which oedema occurs.
Look for evidence of Achilles tendon xanthomata due to hyperlipidemia.
Introduce yourself and your role clearly to the patient.

Explain the procedure, and gain consent from the patient. Be sure to mention any findings will be kept confidential between the treating team. Ensure the patient is adequately exposed and correctly positioned.
Hand hygiene is a simple and effective solution to reduce both the spread of infection and multiresistant germs, and to protect patients from healthcare-associated infection.

The peripheral vascular examination is similar to a diabetic exam, in that the legs are an excellent source of information. Inspect the legs slowly and deliberately, paying attention to any changes in skin color (purple/black from haemostasis) or brown (from hemosiderin deposition due to poor venous blood flow). Also inspect for signs of gangrene (blackening of the extremities). Look for any changes to hair distribution, and be sure to examine between the toes and under the legs for any ulceration. With the patient standing, you can also check for signs of varicose veins.
Assess the temperature of the legs, using the backs of your hands. Start distally, and compare both sides and note any differences.
Check the capillary return by pressing on the nail bed and releasing it. The test is considered normal if color returns within 2 seconds.

Buerger's test involves raising the patient's feet to around 45 degrees. In the presence of poor vascular supply, pallor develops. This test can also be quantified by noting the angle at which pallor begins to occur. After this, then ask the patient to place their feet over the side of the bed, where cyanosis may then develop.
Palpate the abdominal, femoral, popliteal, posterior tibial, and dorsalis pedis. Be sure to feel on both sides, commenting on their strength and character.
Palpate the radial and femoral pulses on one side of the body at the same time. The pulsation should occur around the same time, and a delay may indicate coarctation of the aorta.
Auscultate for any aortic and femoral bruits

Assess sensation changes. Ask the patient if they can feel a cotton ball at their sternum, and with their eyes closed, assess sensation for the peripheries. Be sure to ask if feel 'different' on either side.
Coldness and color may indicate poor peripheral vascular supply. Capillary refill should be within 2 seconds.
Normal ranges: BP 110-135 systolic and 70-85 diastolic, temp 36.1-37.5, SpO2 >96%, RR 12-20
Hand hygiene is a simple and effective solution to reduce both the spread of infection and multiresistant germs, and to protect patients from healthcare-associated infection.

Explain the procedure, and gain consent from the patient. Be sure to mention any findings will be kept confidential between the treating team. Ensure the patient is adequately exposed and correctly positioned.
Introduce yourself and your role clearly to the patient.

Perform a general observation of the patient, noting whether they are comfortable at rest as well as their general well-being. Check for signs of dyspnea. A normal respiratory rate should not exceed 25 breaths per minute (16-25). Make note of any signs of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Is the patient using accessory muscles (sternomastoid, platysma, strap muscles of the neck) to breathe? Are they breathing through pursed lips (used by COPD patients to increase positive pressure during expiration to prevent airway collapse).

Cough is a response to irritation of sensory receptors of the submucosa of the upper airways and bronchi. Check for a bovine cough (vocal cord paralysis), of a muffled wheezy cough (COPD). A loose productive cough may be due to secretion in the case of bronchitis or pneumonia. Look for evidence of sputum, and if present comment on color, volume and the presence or absence of blood. Stridor is due to obstruction of the larynx or trachea (foreign body, tumour, infection). Hoarseness may indicate a recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy, associated with carcinoma of the lung.
Clubbing is due to respiratory disease in 80% of cases. More common causes include primary lung carcinoma, and interstitial fibrosis. Clubbing does NOT occur in cases of COPD and asthma.
Staining of the fingers is actually due to tar staining, as nicotine is colourless; and is a sign of cigarette smoking.

The T1 nerve root is located in the lower trunk of the brachial plexus. Compression of these nerves by a peripheral lung tumour results in muscle wasting of the hypothenar muscles and weakness of finger abduction.
Normal ranges: BP 110-135 systolic and 70-85 diastolic, temp 36.1-37.5, SpO2 >96%, RR 12-20

A flapping tremor (asterixis) should be excluded. Ask the patient to dorsiflex the wrists of the arms outstretched and spread the fingers. a flapping tremor may be occur with increased carbon dioxide (CO2) retention, and is usually due to severe COPD. A bounding pulse is also a sign of increased CO2 retention.

Ask the patient to lift the arms over the head and wait for one minute. Any facial plethora, cyanosis, inspiratory stridor, and non-pulsatile elevation of the jugular venous pressure all occur in superior vena cava obstruction.
Check for facial plethora or cyanosis due to superior vena cava obstruction, which can occur in peripheral lung tumours.
Inspect the eyes for evidence of Horner's syndrome (constricted pupil, partial drooping of the eyelid, and loss of sweating; miosis, ptosis, anhidrosis)

Examine the nasal cavity using a torch and a nasal speculum if available. If no speculum is available, gently tilt the end of the nose to gain a clearer view of the nasal cavity. Polyps are associated with asthma and a deviated septum may result in nasal obstruction. The nasal passage may be inflamed in cases of infection.
Sinusitis is elicited by tapping over the sinuses, in cases of acute sinusitis doing so will be tender for the patient.
Examine underneath the tongue for central cyanosis. The mouth should be inspected for signs of infection.

From in front of the patient, place the forefinger of the right hand on the suprasternal notch and push up and backwards until the trachea is felt. This is uncomfortable for the patient so it needs to be performed gently. If the trachea is displaced, its edge will be felt. The trachea may be displaced TOWARDS the affected side in upper lobe collapse, upper lobe fibrosis, pneumonectomy. It will displace AWAY from the affected side in cases of massive pleural effusion and tension pneumothorax.
Palpate the axillary and cervical lymph nodes, which may be enlarged in lung malignancies and some infections.

Examine the chest wall, noting shape and symmetry. A 'barrel chest' is indicative of COPD. A pigeon chest (pectus carinatum) shape with outward bowing of the sternum and costal cartilage occurs due to chronic childhood respiratory illness. A funnel chest (pectus excavatum) appears as a depression in the sternum and in severe cases may restrict lung capacity. Inspect for scars for evidence of previous lung surgery.

Note expansion during inspiration. Reduced chest wall movement on one side may be due to local fibrosis, consolidation, pleural effusion, or pneumothorax. Bilateral reduction of the chest wall occurs during COPD or diffuse interstitial lung diseases.

Place hands on the chest wall, with fingers around the side of the chest. As the patient take a big breath, expansion between the thumbs should be greater than 5 cm. An over inflated chest in COPD will not expand correctly, and the thumbs will instead move closer together.

Palpate the chest wall with the palm of the hand with the patient repeating 'ninety-nine'. The test is only positive if one side appears different from the other. Asymmetry may be due to consolidation.

Check ribs for localised pain due to fracture, either as a result of trauma, tumour, bone disease or even due to prolonged coughing. Tenderness over the costochondral region is suggestive of costochondritis.

Percuss the anterior, posterior and axillary aspects of the chest wall. Note any regions of increased or decreased resonance. A dull note suggests a solid structure (liver, consolidation, collapsed lung), while 'stony dull' is reserved for pleural effusions of haemothorax. Be sure to move the scapulae out of the way by asking the patient to wrap their arms around the front of their chest, rotating the scapula anteriorly.

Breath sounds should be elicited by asking the patient to breathe through an open mouth. Regions of decreased air entry should be noted, and may be due to COPD, pleural effusion, pneumothorax, pneumonia, neoplasm, and pulmonary collapse. Wheezes tend to be louder on expiration, and are usually the result of COPD (low pitch) or asthma (high pitch). Crackles can be defined in their timing. Early inspiratory crackles suggests small airway disease such as COPD. While late inspiratory crackles can be further defined as fine, medium or coarse. Fine crackles are associated with pulmonary fibrosis, medium crackles with left ventricular failure, and coarse crackles with either pulmonary fibrosis bronchiectasis.
Palpate the liver for signs of enlargement, which may be due to increased venous pressure, or secondary deposition of tumour from a lung carcinoma.
Inspect the legs for signs of swelling or cyanosis. This may suggest cor pulmonale. Also look for signs of deep venous thrombosis.
Hand hygiene is a simple and effective solution to reduce both the spread of infection and multiresistant germs, and to protect patients from healthcare-associated infection.

Explain the procedure, and gain consent from the patient. Be sure to mention any findings will be kept confidential between the treating team. Ensure the patient is adequately exposed and correctly positioned.
Introduce yourself and your role clearly to the patient.

The gastrointestinal examination relies greatly on making astute observations of the patient. From the end of the bed make note of the patients overall appearance. Look for signs of jaundice. This appears as yellow discoloration of the skin from hyperbilirubinemia. Check for signs of wasting or recent weight loss. Folds of loose skin from the abdomen and limbs may be suggestive of recent weight loss. Check for changes in pigmentation. This may be due to haemochromatosis, Addison's disease or an increase in ACTH which leads to increase in melanin production. Changes in mental state may be due to toxic metabolites leading to hepatic encephalopathy. Finally, make sure the patient is lying flat with their head on a single pillow. This relaxes the abdominal muscles and allows for effective abdominal palpation.

In cases of chronic liver disease or other diseases resulting in hypoalbuminaemia, there is paleness in the nail beds. There may be a small region of pink nail bed at the most distal portion of the nail. It is thought to occur due to compression of capillary flow by the extracellular fluid.
Around a third of patients with cirrhosis may have finger clubbing. In addition some cases of inflammatory bowel disease, coeliac disease, and long-standing malnutrition can also cause clubbing.

Also known as 'liver palms', this reddening of the palms can be feature of liver disease. It can also present on the soles of the feet. The aetiology in regards to liver disease remains unknown. Palmar erythema can also occur in pregnancy, thyrotoxicosis, rheumatoid arthritis, and polycythaemia.

Inspect the palmar creases for signs of anaemia by pulling the creases apart. Look for a strong pink color. Pallor in the palmar creases is a late sign of anaemia, which may be due to gastrointestinal blood loss, malabsorption (folate, B12), hemolysis, and chronic disease.

Ask the patient to stretch out their arms in front, separate the fingers, and extend the wrists for 15 seconds. A jerky, irregular flexion-extension at the wrists with lateral movement of the fingers can be due to hepatic encephalopathy. It is characteristic of liver failure, but not diagnostic and can also occur in cardiac, respiratory, and renal failure.
Normal ranges: BP 110-135 systolic and 70-85 diastolic, temp 36.1-37.5, SpO2 >96%, RR 12-20

Large bruises (ecchymoses) may be due to clotting abnormalities. Damage to the liver can result in decreased protein synthesis and a reduction in clotting factors. Obstructive jaundice results in a shortage of bile in the digestive system and may reduce the absorption of fat soluble vitamins such as vitamin K which is used in the production of clotting factors II, VII, IX, and X. Tiny sized bruises (petechiae) may result from chronic alcohol abuse, which can result in thrombocytopenia from a decrease in bone marrow production.
Obstructive or cholestatic jaundice can lead to a severe itch (pruritus) due to a buildup of metabolites usually excreted in bile.
Palpate the axillae for lymphadenopathy and for signs of acanthosis nigricans (brown and black skin papillomas, associated with carcinoma. acromegaly, and diabetes)

Examine the eyes for signs of jaundice (yellowing of the sclera) and anaemia (conjunctival pallor). Rings of brownish green rings and the periphery of the cornea are due to excess deposition of copper and are known as Kayser-Fleischer rings. They are indicative of Wilson's Disease. Xanthelasma a yellow plaques in the periorbital region due to increased serum cholesterol.

Palpate over the parotid region for signs of parotid enlargement. Bilateral enlargement may be due to alcoholism, sarcoidosis, lymphoma, malnutrition, and mumps. Unilateral enlargement may be due to a parotid tumour, tumour infiltration (usually painless and causes a facial nerve palsy) or a salivary calculus. Also examine the submandibular gland, which is most often enlarged due to a calculus.

The mouth represents the beginning of the gastrointestinal tract, and is the most easily accessible location for examination. Remove any false teeth. Look for any gum hypertrophy (Vit C deficiency, gingivitis, leukaemia, phenytoin, pregnancy) and pigmentation (lead poisoning, antimalarial and OCP drugs, addison's disease, malignant melanoma). Fetor (bad breath) may be due to poor oral hygiene, while a sweet smell is characteristic of ketosis. Candidiasis presents as creamy white patches in the mouth, caused by the fungal infection of candida albicans. It may spread to the oesophagus and causes dysphagia. It is often due to immunosuppression, chemotherapy, broad-spectrum antibiotics, alcohol abuse, and HIV infection.

A thickened epithelium with bacterial debris and food particles commonly forms a coating of the tongue (particularly on the posterior aspect), and although often worse in smokers it is rarely a sign of disease. Leukoplakia is a white colored thickening of the mouth and tongue mucosa. It is premalignant, with most causes due to poor dental hygiene, smoking, alcohol, sepsis, and syphilis. Glossitis describes the smooth appearance of the tongue, and is due to atrophy of the papillae with possible ulceration in later stages. This often occurs due to nutritional deficiencies of iron, folate, and B-vitamins. Macroglossia can occur in Down syndrome, acromegaly, amyloid deposition, or tumour infiltration.
The cervical lymph nodes should be palpated, paying particular attention to the left supraclavicular node which may be involved in advanced gastrointestinal or lung malignancy.

These radiating small vessels appear like spider legs, and range in size up to half a centimetre in diameter. They are often found in regions drained via the superior vena cava; in the arms, neck and chest wall. Pressure applied to the vessel blanches the lesion. A finding of greater two or three spider naevi is likely abnormal. They are most often caused by alcoholic cirrhosis, but may also appear in viral hepatitis, and late in pregnancy. Campbell de Morgan spots appear similar, they are benign flat red circular lesions which do not blanch on pressure.
This may be a sign of chronic liver disease, and can be unilateral or bilateral. It can also be caused by the use of the diuretic spironolactone.

The patient should be lying flat with one pillow under the head and the abdomen exposed. Check for signs of 'acute abdomen', with the patient looking unwell and having shallow breathing due to irritation of the peritoneum. Inspect for scars from previous surgery or trauma. Abdominal distention can be caused by the "F's": fat (obesity), fluid (ascites), fetus, flatus (due to bowel obstruction), faeces, 'filthy' big tumour. Look for signs of prominent veins, which become engorged due to portal hypertension.

Reassure the patient and ask to bend the knees slightly, this helps to relax the abdominal wall muscles. Begin palpation across the nine regions beginning with light pressure on each region, before repeating with deep palpation. Look at the patient as you palpate, checking for any signs of tenderness or pain. Guarding occurs when there is contraction of the abdominal muscles, and when done involuntarily suggests peritonitis. Rebound tenderness occurs when the abdominal wall is pressed slowly and then released rapidly. When this causes pain for the patient, it is strongly suggestive of peritonitis.
Palpate lower edge of liver below costal margin. Percuss the liver borders to determine liver size.
Ballot the kidneys, noting that is unusual for the kidneys to be palpable in patient who are not thin.

The spleen is palpated using two hands, the left over the lower left ribs and the right placed below the umbilicus. Move towards the upper right costal margin. A large spleen may be confused with an enlarged right kidney, however the spleen has no palpable upper border (can't get above it).

Percussion over the abdomen is usually resonant due to air in the intestines. Dull percussion notes at the flanks are evident at around 2 litres of fluid. Dullness closer to the midline indicates a more gross ascites.

Listen for active bowel sounds. Absence of sounds over 4 minutes indicates paralytic ileus, while 'tinkling' sounds are louder and more high-pitched. These occur in cases of bowel obstruction due to the presence of air and liquid. Listen for venous hums for signs of portal hypertension and bruits
Noting if it is irreducible, obstructed, or strangulated (red, tense, tender).
This may be a sign of chronic liver disease, and can be unilateral or bilateral. It can also be caused by the use of the diuretic spironolactone.
May occur in the presence of chronic alcohol abuse
Hand hygiene is a simple and effective solution to reduce both the spread of infection and multiresistant germs, and to protect patients from healthcare-associated infection.

Explain the procedure, and gain consent from the patient. Be sure to mention any findings will be kept confidential between the treating team. Ensure the patient is adequately exposed and correctly positioned.
Introduce yourself and your role clearly to the patient.

With the patient laying flat with a pillow under their head, look for signs of wasting and pallor (anaemia). Note their ethnic origin (thalassemia, sickle cell anaemia in Mediterranean and African populations respectively). Check for signs of bruising, jaundice, and scratch marks.
From the greek (koilos-, hollow, onikh-, nail), the presence of 'spoon shaped' nails can be due to severe iron-deficiency anemia. Rarely seen today.
Pallor of the palmar creases suggests a haemoglobin level of less than 70 g/L
Normal ranges: BP 110-135 systolic and 70-85 diastolic, temp 36.1-37.5, SpO2 >96%, RR 12-20. Tachycardia may be present in anaemic patients.
Make sure to note the size and distribution of any bruising. Pinhead sized bruises are petechiae while large bruises are ecchymoses. There may be an underlying coagulation disorder.

Palpate the epitrochlear nodes, as enlarged epitrochlear lymph nodes are usually pathological from local infection or Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. Continue with palpation of the axillary lymph nodes as well.
Check for scleral jaundice, which occurs in the presence of increased destruction of red blood cells.
Conjunctival pallor is indicative of anaemia, and is seen before palmar creases and nail beds. Studies have shown it is most detectable at and below 90Hb.
Conjunctival pallor is indicative of anaemia, and is seen before palmar creases and nail beds. Studies have shown it is most detectable at and below 90Hb.

The mouth should be examined by 'walking' through from the outside to inside. Start at the gums for hypertrophy which can occur with AML or in scurvy. Check for signs of bleeding. Atrophic glossitis (smooth tongue) occurs in megaloblastic anaemia and iron deficiency anaemia. Check to see if there is any tonsillar enlargement.

Examine the cervical lymph nodes from behind, making note to mention the different groups as you palpate: Submental, submandibular, sublingual, anterior and posterior triangle, occipital, pre and post auricular. Finally be sure to palpate the supraclavicular lymph nodes when the patient's shoulders shrugged.

Explain this procedure to the patient before you proceed. Begin by gently tapping over the spinal column with a fist. Infiltration within the marrow causes enlargement, which may be painful. This occurs in myeloma, lymphoma or carcinoma. Also gently push on the sternum, and push both shoulder girdles towards each other.
Hand hygiene is a simple and effective solution to reduce both the spread of infection and multiresistant germs, and to protect patients from healthcare-associated infection.

Explain the procedure, and gain consent from the patient. Be sure to mention any findings will be kept confidential between the treating team. Ensure the patient is adequately exposed and correctly positioned.
Introduce yourself and your role clearly to the patient.

Make an observation about the patient's weight and signs of obesity. Note if they appear dehydrated, have deep laboured breathing (Kussmaul's) both which can occur in the presence of diabetic ketoacidosis. This is due to an increase in fat metabolism as a response to lack of glucose. Look for any obvious pigmentation changes, which may be due haemochromatosis (bronze diabetes).

The lower limbs in a diabetic examination is a high yield area, as many of the physical signs first appear here. Look for loss of hair and skin atrophy due to small-vessel disease. Diabetics are more prone to skin infections such as cellulitis and fungal infections due to high tissue glucose making a good beneficial environment for organisms.
One of the most common complications of diabetes, ulcers occur particularly on the toes and the feet. They occur as a result of ischaemia and peripheral neuropathy.
Palpate injection sites for fat atrophy or hypertrophy. Check all peripheral pulses and temperature for evidence of peripheral vascular disease.
Assess to reflexes and proximal muscle power. Using a monofilament, assess peripheral sensation.
Check the nails for signs of Candida infection.
Normal ranges: BP 110-135 systolic and 70-85 diastolic, temp 36.1-37.5, SpO2 >96%, RR 12-20. Blood sugar levels should also be tested (random levels should be below 11 mmol)
A random blood glucose test result that is between 5.5 - 11.0 mmol/L should be investigated further with an Oral Glucose Tolerance Test.
In addition to small-vessel retinal disease, diabetes also affects the lens due to hyperglycaemia and water retention. Test visual acuity using a snellen chart.
Using an ophthalmoscope examine the eyes, paying particular attention to any retinal changes and proliferative disease.
Assess the III, IV, and VI cranial nerves
Palpate and auscultate the carotid arteries
There may be liver enlargement due to fatty infiltration or haemochromatosis
Check for presence of protein and glucose using a dipstick. One of the first signs of diabetic nephropathy is microalbuminuria however this is dipstick negative and requires its own dipstick/test.
Hand hygiene is a simple and effective solution to reduce both the spread of infection and multiresistant germs, and to protect patients from healthcare-associated infection.

Explain the procedure, and gain consent from the patient. Be sure to mention any findings will be kept confidential between the treating team. Ensure the patient is adequately exposed and correctly positioned.
Introduce yourself and your role clearly to the patient.
Make note of the patient's gait and note any gross deformities. Throughout the examination make sure to compare sides.
Look for any wasting of the quadriceps muscle. Quadriceps wasting may occur rapidly when the knee is injured.
Inspect for changes to the skin around the knee; scars, swelling, and deformities. Scars may be from previous surgery such as arthroscopy.
Localised swellings caused by loose cartilaginous bodies may move around when the knee joint moves.
Check for fixed flexion deformity by squatting down to look at the knee side-on, there will be a space below the knee if this is present.
Check for patella subluxation by asking the patient to flex and then extend the leg at the knee.
Feel for wasting of the quadriceps

Feel for warmth and swelling around the knee. Fixed lumps in the line of the joint might be meniscal cysts. An early sign of effusion is loss of peripatellar grooves. Synovial swelling and effusion if present is usually found medial to the patella.

One hand presses down on the leg just superior to the patella, compressing any fluid that may be present, while the other hand is used to push down on the patella. The test is positive if the patella sinks down and then a 'tap' is felt as the patella rests on the femur. This test is used for large effusions.

Use your left hand to compress the suprapatellar pouch, and with your right hand run your fingers along the groove beside the patella on one side then the other. The test is positive if there is bulging on the opposite side due to fluid. This is used for small effusions.
Check for these by sliding the patella sideways, over the femoral condyles.

Normal to 135 degrees. Feel for crepitus while moving the joint. While the knee is in the flexed position, feel along the joint line at the patella ligament and at the sites of attachment of the collateral ligaments.
Normal to 5 degrees. Feel for crepitus while moving the joint.

Hold the patient's leg off the bed in a slightly flexed position. Rest your forearm along the length of the tibia. Test the lateral and medial movement of the leg at the knee joint, while stabilising the upper leg with your other hand at the thigh. Movement of more than 5-10 degrees is abnormal.

Have the patient flex their knee to 90 degrees. Stabilise the patient's foot on the bed with your elbow and run your arm along the tibia, grasping the tibia near the knee with both hands. Attempt to move the leg anterior and then posterior, checking for movement by placing your thumbs along the joint margins. Movement of more than 5-10 degrees is abnormal.
Mention, but do not perform this test for patella subluxation.
In the prone position look and feel for Baker's cyst. Pressure diverticulum of the synovial membrane occurring through a hiatus in the knee capsule.

In the prone position, flex the patient's knee to 90 degrees. Stabilise the thigh with one hand and use the other hand to press down at the foot and rotate the leg backwards and forwards. The test is positive if the patient experiences pain or clicking, and indicates meniscal damage.
Opposite to the Apley's grinding test, the leg is pulled upwards to take strain off the menisci. If this test is positive, it indicates a ligamentous abnormality.

Patient is supine, knee flexed at 90 degrees. Hold the ankle with one hand and with the other push on the medial aspect of the knee to produce valgus force. Extend the patients leg while applying this pressure and use your hand at their ankle to rotate the leg internally and then externally. The test is positive if there is a popping sensation, which may be followed by inability to extend the knee. Positive test indicates possible meniscal tear.
Hand hygiene is a simple and effective solution to reduce both the spread of infection and multiresistant germs, and to protect patients from healthcare-associated infection.

Explain the procedure, and gain consent from the patient. Be sure to mention any findings will be kept confidential between the treating team. Ensure the patient is adequately exposed and correctly positioned.
Introduce yourself and your role clearly to the patient.

Ask the patient to exposure the chest and shoulder girdle. Pay attention while this occurs for any limitation or discomfort. Check for any signs of asymmetry. Throughout the examination make sure to compare sides.
Inspect for changes to the skin around the shoulder and clavicles; scars, swelling, and deformities. Scars may be from previous surgery such as arthroscopy.
Localised swellings caused by loose cartilaginous bodies may move around when the shoulder joint moves. Effusions are difficult to see unless they are large and the patient is thin.
Look for any asymmetry and check that the hands are held at the same level as well as looking for any muscle wasting.
Palpate along the sternoclavicular joint, moving outwards to feel the clavicle, the shoulder girdle, and the scapula.
Normal to 180 degrees, feel around the acromioclavicular joint as you move the patients arm.
Normal to 65 degrees, feel around the acromioclavicular joint as you move the patients arm.
Normal to 90 degrees, feel around the acromioclavicular joint as you move the patients arm.
Normal to 50 degrees, feel around the acromioclavicular joint as you move the patients arm.
Normal to 65 degrees, feel around the acromioclavicular joint as you move the patients arm.
Normal to 90 degrees, feel around the acromioclavicular joint as you move the patients arm.
Test this by asking the patient to flex their elbow against resistance. A ruptured biceps tendon will cause the muscle to contract into a ball

A quick 3 step test to assess shoulder movement. Standing behind the patient, ask them to scratch an imaginary itch over the opposite scapula by reaching over the opposite shoulder, then by reaching behind the neck, and finally by reaching behind their back.
Look for this as you test abduction and adduction. If there is pain or the patient is unable to continue the movement between 45-135 degrees this suggests supraspinatus tendinitis.

Have the patient hold their arms out in front of them at 90 degrees, slightly wider than their shoulders, with their thumbs down. Ask the patient to resist your downward pressure on their forearms. The test is positive if this causes pain, and suggests supraspinatus tendonitis.
Mention, but do not perform this test for anterior stability/subluxation of the shoulder joint.
Hand hygiene is a simple and effective solution to reduce both the spread of infection and multiresistant germs, and to protect patients from healthcare-associated infection.

Explain the procedure, and gain consent from the patient. Be sure to mention any findings will be kept confidential between the treating team. Ensure the patient is adequately exposed and correctly positioned.
Introduce yourself and your role clearly to the patient.
Look for muscle wasting, scars, fasciculations. Note the presence of urinary catheters.
Ask the patient to walk away, turn quickly and then walk towards you, assessing their gait as they do so.
Assesses for L4 or L5 lesion.
Squat or stand from low chair

Patient stands upright, feet together, eyes open initially, then closed for up to a minute. Assess the change in stability once eyes closed. Positive if marked unsteadiness when patient closes their eyes. Positive test indicates loss of proprioceptive sensation.
Place a hand under the knee and quickly pull upwards to produce flexion, then support the thigh and move the lower leg quickly between flexion and extension. Feel for resistance to the movement.

Ankle - sharply dorsiflex foot with knee bent, thigh in external rotation. Knee - with the leg straight, resting on the bed, place hand superior to patella, over the tendon and sharply pull down towards the feet. Clonus indicates an upper motor neuron lesion.
Gluteus medius and minimus, sartorius, tensor fasciae latae - L4, L5, S1
Adductors longus, brevis and magnus - L2, L3, L4
Tibialis anterior, extensor digitorum longus, extensor hallucis longus - L4, L5
Peroneus longus and brevis, extensor digitorum longus - L5, S1
Tibialis posterior, gastrocnemius, hallucis longus - L5, S1

L5, S1, S2. Use a blunt object to stroke up the lateral aspect of the sole and curve inwards before you get to the toes. The normal response in patients over the age of one year is flexion of the big toe at the MTP joint. Abnormal response is due to upper motor neuron lesion.

Ask the patient to rest the heel of one foot on the shin on the other leg and then move it up and down the shin as accurately as they can at a moderate pace. Cerebellar disease prevents them from doing this.
Ask the patient to lift their foot to touch your finger with their big toe. Repeat this a few times, moving your finger in between. Look for an intention tremor.
Ask the patient to tap the sole of their foot quickly and rhythmically on your hand.
Test a patch in each dermatome and map any abnormal areas.
Test first over ankles, moving up to knee and/or hip as required.
Test at toes first, again, moving to knee and/or hip as required.
Test a patch in each dermatome and map any abnormal areas.
Hand hygiene is a simple and effective solution to reduce both the spread of infection and multiresistant germs, and to protect patients from healthcare-associated infection.

Explain the procedure, and gain consent from the patient. Be sure to mention any findings will be kept confidential between the treating team. Ensure the patient is adequately exposed and correctly positioned.
Introduce yourself and your role clearly to the patient.
Inspect both the shoulder girdles and the arms for signs of increased or decreased muscle bulk. Note any abnormal posture or abnormal movements such as a tremor.

Test for arm drift by asking the patient to shut their eyes, hold their arms out straight and then turn their palms upwards. Cerebellar drift is usually upwards, while upper motor lesions often cause a downward drift due to muscle weakness. Other causes include loss of proprioception, which usually only affects the fingers.

Abduction (C5,C6: deltoid, supraspinatus) is done with the elbows flexed and the patient resists the push downwards. Adduction (C6,C7,C8: pectoralis major, latissimus dorsi) is completed in the opposite manner.

Flexion (C5,C6: biceps, brachialis) is completed with the patient bending their elbows and not allowing the examiner to straighten them out. Extension (C7,C8: triceps) is completed in the opposite manner.
Flexion (C6,C7: flexor carpi ulnaris, radialis) the patient should bend their wrist and resist. Extension (C7,C8: extensor carpi group)
Extension (C7,C8) the patient should straighten their fingers and not allow them to be pushed down. Flexion (C7,C8) Abduction (C8,T1), Adduction (C8,T1)

Ask the patient to touch their nose with their index finger, and then to your forefinger and almost full extension. Repeat the test a few times with both the eyes open and closed. Past-pointing is associated with cerebellar disease.

The patient should pronate and supinate their hand as rapidly as possible, 'tapping' their front and back of their hand on their opposite hand. In cerebellar disease the motion is slow and awkward, this is termed dysdiadochokinesis.
Ask the patient to lift their arms rapidly from their sides and then stop. Hypotonia from cerebellar disease causes a delay in the ability to stop the arms.

Assess by grasping the distal interphalangeal joint from the sides, and moving up and down. The patient should be able to indicate which direction the movement is in. If unable to do so, assess the wrists and then arms.

Spinothalamic pathway (pain and temperature). Using a new monofilament, demonstrate to the patient by placing on the sternum. Then ask them to close their eyes and assess sensation on each dermatome, beginning proximally. Compare both the right and left sides noting any differences.
Spinothalamic pathway (pain and temperature). Can be simply done using a metal tuning fork.

Posterior column (vibration and proprioception). Use a 128 Hz tuning fork (the smaller 256 Hz tuning fork is used to assess hearing) and with the patients eyes closed assess using the distal interphalangeal joints.
Test by touching the skin with the end of cotton wool. The patient should close their eyes, and indicate when they are being touched. Test each dermatome and compare both sides.
Hand hygiene is a simple and effective solution to reduce both the spread of infection and multiresistant germs, and to protect patients from healthcare-associated infection.

Explain the procedure, and gain consent from the patient. Be sure to mention any findings will be kept confidential between the treating team. Ensure the patient is adequately exposed and correctly positioned.
Introduce yourself and your role clearly to the patient.
Inspect the patient for scars, particularly from craniotomy, the skin for neurofibromas, and the face for asymmetry and ptosis
Inspect the skin around the nose, noting any rashes. Next inspect the inside of the nose by elevating the tip and using a torch
Usually the CNI is not tested unless the patient complains of anosmia, but it is worth mentioning.
Inspect the skin around the eyes and then the eyes themselves, noting asymmetry, ptosis, rashes, dryness, redness or pupil deformities.
The patient wears their glasses or contact lenses for this test using a Snellen's chart

Ask the patient to remove their glasses or contact lenses for this test. Ensure your eyes are level with the patient's. Preferably, use a red tipped pin for this test, but if one is not available, or if the patient cannot see it, you may use your hand, wiggling your fingers.
Map the patient's blind spot. Usually an enlarged blind spot is only detected if it is grossly enlarged.
Begin with the red reflex, and move in until the fundus is visualised.
CN III, CN IV, C VI - oculomotor, trochlear, abducens
Check each pupil and also the consensual response.
Inability to accommodate with other tests normal may be due to a midbrain lesion or cortical blindness.
Test movements of the eye using the 'H' test, noting any inability of movement, double vision, or nystagmus.
Mention, but do not perform this test for function of the ophthalmic division of the CNV (sensory) and facial nerve (motor).
Test all three divisions (ophthalmic, maxillary, mandibular) of the nerve using a neurological pin and then cottonwool.
Ask the patient to clench their teeth while palpating over the temporal and then masseter muscles. Then ask the patient to hold their mouth open while you try to shut it (pterygoid muscles).
Normal reflex is slight movement or no movement at all. If there is a strong reaction, this may indicate a pseudobulbar palsy
Look for asymmetry of the face, particularly drooping of one side of the mouth.
Ask the patient to look up and resist you pushing down above their eyebrows.
Check strength by trying to open the patients eyes.
Check strength by pushing cheeks in.
Taste on anterior two-thirds of tongue
Not usually tested, but worth mentioning.
Remove hearing aids if present. Examine the external ear noting scars or signs of inflammation.
A normal tympanic membrane is pearly grey and concave in shape. note any signs of inflammation, wax, secretions or perforations.
Block one ear by placing a finger over the external auditory meatus and moving it around while you whisper into the other ear two numbers (usually 68 and 100). This is a quick test for hearing loss.

Use a 256 Hz vibrating tuning fork for this test. The tuning fork is placed on the mastoid process and then when the patient no longer hears it, it is brought forward to be in line with the external meatus where it is normally heard again. The test is negative, indicating conduction (middle ear) deafness if the sound is not heard at the external meatus.

Use a 256 Hz vibrating tuning fork. Position the fork on the centre of the forehead. Normally, the sound should be heard in the middle of the forehead. If there is nerve deafness, the sound is heard best in the normal ear. If there is conduction deafness, the sound is heard better in the abnormal ear.

Using a torch, inspect the inside of the mouth, particularly noting any displacement of the uvula. Ask the patient to say 'ah' and note any asymmetrical movement of the soft palate (velum) and uvula. The uvula will deviate towards the normal side.
Mention, but do not perform this test for function of the CNIX (sensory) and CNX (motor) nerves.
Ask the patient to speak to assess for unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve lesion.
Ask the patient to cough to assess for recurrent laryngeal nerve lesion.
Taste on posterior third of tongue

Using a torch, inspect the inside of the mouth, particularly noting any displacement of the uvula. Ask the patient to say 'ah' and note any asymmetrical movement of the soft palate (velum) and uvula. The uvula will deviate towards the normal side. Gag reflex Mention, but do not perform this test for function of the CNIX (sensory) and CNX (motor) nerves. Speech Ask the patient to speak to assess for unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve lesion. Cough Ask the patient to cough to assess for recurrent laryngeal nerve lesion. Taste on posterior third of tongue Not usually tested. Swallow Test ability to swallow using a sip of water.
Test ability to swallow using a sip of water.
Ask the patient to shrug their shoulders and resist you pushing down.
Ask the patient to turn their head to one side and resist you pushing it back the other way. Repeat on the other side.
Ask the patient to open their mouth and inspect the tongue on the floor of the mouth. Note any wasting or fasciculations. Ask the patient to protrude their tongue. It deviates to the affected side
